column8: looking for specific use cases not covered by documentation, practical experience and opinions
column9: string search, tags in stackoverflow, google
column10: find my use case in the least possible time
column11: brief and to the point, copy paste solution, knowledge of the poster, reputation points of the poster
column15: actively maintained, easy to replace, simple to use
column16: Stackoverflow presents a sidebar with questions having similar strings and tags. In forums, people looks for solutions, not opinions.
column17: Activity on a certain technology indicates that knowledge will be relevant.

column8: Other people have different areas of expertise. To prevent/repair unduly biased insight/opinions I may hold. To check out alternative methods/angles of attack. Find industry best practices.
column9: Google usually gets me to the main post I need then I check upvotes, reputation on other answers, quoted sources etc.
column10: StackOverflow does not like opinions, neither do I. I like my choices to be based on more than my personal opinion or preference.
column11: Quoted sources, insightful body of text, reputation.
column15: Compatibility with existing software core, ease of use for the enduser, licensing.

column8: I see a thing the first time and maybe even don't know the terminology, and users may already have at least some experience. And no runnable example in official docs (if any).
column9: Using multiple search results, using links from answers and comments, using related questions on SO
column10: Too new or unpopular technology => not enough content availble. Or too specific need nobody else seem to care about.
column11: Consistency with other opinions around, stated opinion about other unrelated things, general post quality (formatting, spelling, good code, not too short).
column15: I rarely choose APIs in general, usually it is dictated by business need.
column16: Simplest, trivial way is to read the first encountered post and "call it a day". More thorough way is to read (or glance though) multiple posts, feed them into intuition, then ask the intuition.
column17: Maybe API quality someday, if such rankings would be advertised to the men in suits.
column18: Much more spammy "grass-rooting" positive self-reviews to bump the said rating. The process described two question above will include a "is it a real post or fake?" step.

column8: Facts > opinions. I like hearing about practical issues from other devs with experience using an API. Undocumented issues, bugs or other quirks for example.
column9: I mainly use Google. Sometimes I use the Stack Overflow search box. I very rarely use other dev. forum's search/browse features unless I'm looking for something very specific or something that I've read before.
column10: SO's biggest strength is that it's a search/answer site more than a forum. It's not a good place for lengthy discussions or opinionated debates. My biggest challenge is comparing different API's and technologies, because the "truth" tends to get subjective or very dependent on your use case.
column11: People's epxerience using it. Especially when up-to-date and from people that tried competing technologies in production.
column14: No not "to navigate", the question asked about "rely on tools to help you understand opinions about APIs". We sometimes use in-house benchmarks to verify other's opinions. We like data, not opinions :)
column15: I have found that I/my team rarely has the chance to choose APIs. We're mostly building APIs for others. The main factors for our customers seems to be 1) accessing valuable information through the API 2) timeliness of the API (latency and "push" APIs) 3) reliability, someone's service/product could become unavailable if your API is down.
column16: Side-by-side such as https://db-engines.com/en/system/Cassandra%3BCouchbase%3BRiak+KV and plots like on g2crowd https://www.g2crowd.com/categories/nosql-databases are sometimes useful.
column17: Either I don't understand the question or it seems a bit leading.
column30: Developer forums (e.g., Stack Overflow);IRC chats;Internal Mailing list;Co-workers

column8: Clarifications on vague, or lack of API documentation
column9: Google search. Quickly skim the answers looking for the most informative ones
column10: Evaluating the relevancy of the opinion to the problem I'm facing.
column11: Grammar, clarity, formatting, examples and links.
column18: Reviews should be done as suggestion for improving the API. Having this nearer to the API documentation helps more than having it in developer forums.
column30: Developer forums (e.g., Stack Overflow);Respective API documentation

column6: StackOverflow, Apple Dev Forums, Ray Wenderlich
column9: Usually via google search results, will check for a pattern from multiple sources about a single API aim interested in
column10: Reliable and up to date info
column11: How old the forum post is, the quality of the answer and the reputation of the author
column15: Reputation, vendor, reliability, source visibility (open source etc), activity (last updated)
column16: I'm not sure. It's hard to keep up to date as everything evolves so frequently
